column1: The carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) test measures the level of CEA in the blood.
CEA is a protein normally found in the tissue of a developing baby in the womb.

This test is done to monitor the response to treatment and then to check for the return of colon and other cancers such as medullary thyroid cancer and cancers of the rectum, lung, breast, liver, pancreas, stomach, and ovaries.
A high CEA level in a person recently treated for certain cancers may mean the cancer has returned.

An increased CEA level may also be due to: - Liver and gallbladder problems, such as scarring of the liver (cirrhosis), or gallbladder inflammation (cholecystitis) - Heavy smoking - Inflammatory bowel diseases (such as ulcerative colitis or diverticulitis) - Lung infection - Inflammation of the pancreas (pancreatitis) - Stomach ulcer
